charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
On Friday the 5th (until Sunday the 7th) of March I will be taking part in the David Goggins Challenge and will be running four miles every four hours for forty-eight hours, this will accumulate to 48 miles which is the equivalent of more than a marathon and a half in two days!

Like many people, Cancer has unfortunately affected many people in my life and I have seen firsthand the devastating effect it can have. I have chosen to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support as I believe the work they put in to help not only the people suffering from cancer but also their families is incredible and I want to make sure they can continue to support these families for as long as they need to.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and if you could donate anything it would be truly appreciated! 

Thanks, Curt x

story:
We are raising money to help to support those directly or indirectly affected by Cancer and will be raising money for Macmillan Cancer Support.

Macmillan offer emotional, physical and financial support
to people who are diagnosed with cancer whilst also providing advice and support those around them. They campaign to fight for real change and to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can.

We will kick off the new initiative Monday, 1st March where
we will be committing to a walk a minimum of 10,000  steps a day throughout March. Trying to do more walking 121's and taking breaks way from our desks

Many thanks for your participation and support!

story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising.

Leyton will be 10 on 4th March, he shares his birthday with his Grandad Alan Johnston who would've been 70. Unfortunately Leyton did not get to meet his grandad as he passed away before he was born. In September 2020 Leyton lost his Granny Ann Smith.  Leyton has now lost 2 grandparents to this terrible disease 😢. 

During the month of March Leyton  is going to take on the challenge of completing 100km to raise money for this great charity. 

If you can spare a £ or 2 please donate. We would really appreciate your support.  Thank you 😊

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Im trying to raise as much money as i can for Macmillan Cancer in memory of my Mum who passed away with this horrible disease when i was only 3 years old, leaving behind myself and my Downs-Syndrome brother. I will be cycling 300 miles over the course of March, which works out to be around 6.5 miles a day. Cancer is one of the main causes of death around the world and unfortunately one way or another we have all been affected in some form. I will be uploading my cycle on a daily basis!

If i hit the 300 mile target, i will then start doing 10 miles a day!

Toolstation are proud to be partnering with Macmillan Cancer Support for the next two years.There are currently 3 million people living with cancer in the UK, with someone receiving a cancer diagnosis every two minutes. We know that one in two people in the UK will experience a cancer diagnosis in their lifetime.For more than 100 years Macmillan has been there for people with cancer when they needed them most. Today is no exception!Cancer is not going anywhere. And neither can Macmillan.Join us in supporting Macmillan, so they can keep providing physical, financial and emotional support to the millions of people that count on them.

Lets kick cancers A**

story:
Hello, thank you for supporting my fundraising.

Whilst on Furlough I want to try to do something to give back. 

I'm lucky to work for a very supportive company who encourage us in many ways, and who also offer support to charities including Macmillan. 

I'm aiming to walk 5k a day during the month of March to raise £155, that's £1 per kilometer if you'd like!! 

I absolutely know everyone is struggling during this pandemic, charities especially, so anything you can give is so much appreciated, even if it's just a share of my page. 

I just want to give something back and put my time to good use for something very worthwhile. 

Below is an explanation from Macmillan detailing how Just Giving works. 

Thank you for your support and any donations given, it means the world. 

Hayley Dalrymple. 

At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
What is the 4x4x48 Challenge and why is it difficult?

The challenge is simple. Run 4 miles every 4 hours for 48 hours straight. That’s almost 2 marathons in 2 days.

Despite its simplicity, the 4x4x48 is a pressing test of resilience, endurance and willpower. Whilst 4 miles isn’t a major strain for most athletes, it’s the frequency of needing to run them which makes this challenge tough.

Because you have to put in 4 miles every 4 hours, you can’t get quality sleep. Sure, you might get the odd two and a half hours but the alarm bell will soon ring ordering you out of the comfortable bed and into the running shoes for another 4 miles.

Some find the wear and tear on the body particularly difficult. The first three or four 4-mile runs will be fine for most athletes but the constant running will soon result wear you out. Your muscles will start feeling sorer as the challenge progresses, and each run will become harder to maintain than the last.

The 4x4x48 challenge is also tough due to the willpower required. It’s easy to motivate yourself to run once or maybe even twice in a day but having to do so 12 times in 2 days is a sheer willpower test. Whilst you may be reading this thinking ‘easy, I’ll be able to take that on’, I guarantee you that (from personal experience) it’s a totally different conversation you’ll have with yourself when it’s 4AM on the second day and you’re exhausted.
title: Anthony / Chris / Scott / Leon 4x4x48

story:
I am doing fundraising for 3 charities this year. The first is Macmillan.

My best friends Mum was diagnosed with cancer and sadly passed away in October 2019.  I have decided to do some fundraising for a charity of his choice. 
He chose Macmillan as he and his father were so grateful for all the help and support they received during one of darkest moments of their lives.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
In December 2019 my husband, was diagnosed with prostate cancer and so our world fell apart. We dealt with the news in our own way. Lots of emotions, fear, anger, sadness, all at once. Understanding treatments and impacts they will have. Then frustration and worry as COVID delayed treatment. Macmillan provided a very much needed emotional support for which we will be forever grateful.

Cancer is frightening and affects everyone in the family. It is so important to have someone to reach out to.

So here we are, my two sons, Max, Alex and me are taking on the Thames Path Mighty Hike challenge and joining others in a 26 miles hike along the river Thames on 17th July 2021.

Thanks for supporting our fundraising. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs

Thank you
Anna, Max, Alex

charity.name: St John Ambulance
story:
The St John Ambulance Norfolk County Priory Group are delighted to once again be running their annual
Norfolk Open Gardens.

Between April and June, you will be able to visit six exclusive gardens across the county. Each has a rich history which is reflected throughout the picturesque grounds.

For more information about the Open Gardens, including dates and times and booking information, please do visit the garden page here:   https://stjohnopengardensgmail.weebly.com/

If you are unable to attend the Open Gardens we would be grateful if you would still consider giving a donation  to help St John Ambulance ease the strain during the COVID-19 outbreak. Our dedicated St John Ambulance volunteers are standing by to relieve pressure on our NHS by boosting the health response in communities across the country.

The St John Ambulance Norfolk County Priory Group is grateful to all the owners of the gardens that are being opened to the public in support of St John Ambulance.

Hear from Georgina Holloway, CPG Chair and County President for Norfolk, by clicking here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6tOGahLa7oQ&feature=youtu.be to learn about her motivations for setting up the Norfolk Open Gardens and why we need your support today.
title: St John's Norfolk Open Gardens 2021

Name: St John's Norfolk Open Gardens 2021

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: TOUGH RUNNER ULTIMATE TRIFECTA-50 MILES, 100 MILES or 200 MILES
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.
title: Kier Group and the British Heart Foundation partnership
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Subtext: TOUGH RUNNER ULTIMATE TRIFECTA-50 MILES, 100 MILES or 200 MILES
Name: Kier Group and the British Heart Foundation partnership

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Anyone who knows me, knows how much I love all things chocolate so giving it up for a month is going to be TOUGH!!!! (Especially now Ferrero Rocher bunnies are in the shops!).

But its not as tough as being told my 10 week old son needed open heart surgery that he probably wasn't well enough to survive. The thought of having to say goodbye to your own child is something no parent should ever go through. 

Thankfully, he did survive and nearly 25 years later he is still thriving and that is all down to the hard work, dedication and continued research of both the British Heart Foundation and Great Ormond Street hospital. 

Giving up chocolate for a month is the least I can do as a small thank you for saving my sons life. Please sponsor me if you can, so they can carry on saving lives. 

Thank you xxx

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Our lovely mam, Christine (Chris) was beautiful inside and out. She was never too busy to stop for a chat, nothing was too much trouble, and she always put everyone’s needs ahead of her own. She loved to sing,  bake, play with the grandchildren and loved anything that was “old fashioned”. 

Suddenly and unexpectedly, she suffered a ruptured aortic aneurysm on 22nd Feb leaving us all shocked and devastated. We have had an overwhelming amount of love and support from those whose lives she touched, and we just wanted to invite you to donate in her memory to potentially help others to access resources and testing in the future.

Thank you

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting our page. We are raising money for the British Heart Foundation and would be so grateful for your support. 

We at Ledbury CC have decided to Run, Walk, Swim, Cycle, Cross Trainer our way to the total number of miles it would take to travel around all of the County Cricket Grounds in addition to all of the Test Match venues from and to our home ground in Ledbury (even though we will have already been to them once), a total of 2150 miles

This idea was borne out of realising we would not get much pre-season cricket training due to Covid-19 and we wanted to do a collective challenge in memory of our groundsman Geoff Fletcher who sadly passed away.

14 of us have signed up to the challenge, so that's 153 miles each in 60 days (although we are expecting cyclist Brandon to pick up the slack!).

We would love your support for this worthwhile cause, if this is successful apparently organiser Gordon has an even bigger challenge lined up for the summer!

Thank You for your support!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!
title: Ledbury's Around the Grounds in 60 days

Name: Ledbury's Around the Grounds in 60 days

story: Over the last few years, we have lost close members of our family to heart disease in sudden and heartbreaking ways. Being part of the BAME community, we are at a higher risk of developing heart and coronary diseases. That’s why this year we are aiming to raise some money for a great cause and help make a difference. Please help us reach our target!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
A couple of weeks ago Natalie said she was going to do the Dechox for March to raise money for the British Heart Foundation. So knowing how much we like our chocolate and it's Mini Egg season. In moment of paternal solidarity (or foolishness) I shouted up, I'll do it with you
So now in just over 2 days time for 1 month it's no chocolate, sweets or fizzy pop. Well I could have been totally mad and signed up for Dry January, so at least I can have an odd beer. 
So do I drink the last can of Irn-Bru this weekend or leave it the Fridge to taunt me for a month? Good luck Natalie!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Ryan and I will be giving up all things chocolate, along with fizzy drinks, to help raise money for the British Heart Foundation. Anyone who knows me will understand that chocolate is my absolute weakness. I have it EVERYDAY. Whereas Ryan's weakness is Pepsi Max (or any other fizzy alternative available).  This really will be a challenge for us but trying to get healthier whilst raising money for charity can only be a good thing, right? We appreciate that this is not the easiest time to be donating, but ask if you can spare anything, no matter how small, for such a great charity.

Many thanks in advance. 

The withdrawal symptoms will be a real thing for sure and I promise, if either of us fail (we won't!!), then we shall personally donate an additional £50 each and everytime. And trust me, as new parents, that isn't an option, haha.


From BHF:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Hello,

We decided we really wanted to do something for BHF so myself and Lemi are giving up chocolate for March!! 😅 As most of you know Lemi had open heart surgery in July 2019 and she is doing amazingly due to the research they do. We honestly count our blessings everyday that she broke her leg (sounds crazy we know) but it wasn’t until her Pre-op for her leg that her ASD came to light. Lemi had two large holes in her heart and it was 3 times the size it should of been. But thanks to all the amazing surgeons/doctors/nurses/staff at Southampton Hospital and all the research BHF do, She is fighting fit now 💪🏻 ❤️

My Dad and God Mother Maggie died from heart conditions 💔 as do so many others. It’s the worlds biggest killer! I also suffered with heart failure in pregnancy with Arlo. (I’m good now)

So in conclusion the heart is so scarily delicate but equally strong!! They need funding more now than ever. 

Please donate what you can or share.

Thank you so much.

Loads of love Lemi & Lou 

From BHF - The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: February happens to be Marfan Syndrome Awareness Month, and it was also my 18th birthday this month. I and many others have cardiac issues, and research is vital for supporting people such as myself to improve quality of life and even sometimes cure their illnesses. I know many people (including family members) who have experienced major cardiac events, or have heart conditions they couldn't cope with without medications, surgery, or other things that require extensive research and funding. So, if you can spare a little money or even just share this page, I'll be extremely grateful! I won't be eating sweets, chocolate, or having ANY fizzy drinks this month to help fundraise, so wish me luck!!
title: Katie's Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Hi All,

I am giving up chocolate for one month and may be a few sweeties for BHF.

This is going to be hard, I'm only 6yrs, but my daddy and mummy are going to do it with me.

As we all know, my daddy had major heart surgery in June 2020, which was very unexpected and also complicated.  I was so sad and thought I wouldn't see my daddy again.

If it was not for the doctors and nurses at Glenfield Hospital, my daddy wouldn't be here to day with me and mummy and all of our family and friends.

So, if you could help me raise as much money/pennies by donating to my fundraising, that will be brilliant.

For every donation given, if daddy or mummy has your phone number, you will receive a little surprise from me!!!

Thank you for your support!

Mason

XxX

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Bit more about BHF Dectox below:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

You may know, I had covid in September and whilst I was absolutely fine when I had it, I’ve been suffering with post viral/long covid symptoms since. That has meant that I’m pretty much useless beyond a day at work, and am really struggling with pain after minimal exercise. So I’m struggling with shifting my lockdown boredom eating weight (!) and doing any fitness based challenges. This feels like the perfect alternative! Therefore, I will be cutting out all sweets, chocolate, cakes and biscuits hoping to raise money and make a long term diet change!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: As many of you know, I lost my nan to heart disease a couple of years ago and have never really gotten over it. She was my 'go to' person and my rock. So as I'm a huge chocoholic and can munch a large bar of chocolate most nights, I thought the Dechox challenge, would be a good motivation for me getting back on track to healthy eating and raise a bit of money for cause close to my heart.

Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
My name is Elizabeth and I’m 24-years-old from the North East of England. Over the past two and a half years I’ve lost all of my grandparents. It hasn’t been easy. First my Granda to cancer, secondly my Nana to a heart attack, and thirdly my Grandma to COVID.

Its awful to see people around you suffering, so I want to try and do as much as I can to help others – this is why I’m taking part in the British Heart Foundation Dechox. Throughout the month I will not consuming chocolate or sweets (which is going to be hard because I’ve just discovered putting Nutella in my porridge lol) as well as aiming to walk at least 10,000 steps a day.

Living in a western world gives us the opportunity to often indulge without really thinking we are – think about how many fast foods restaurants are now just part of a weekly routine or how having a packet of crisps or bar of chocolate is classes as a daily essential for many. I think it’s time we changed our habits to create a healthier world and a happier heart.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Anyone who knows me knows how much of a chocoholic I am, and therefore how much of a challenge this will be for me! However, a couple of things have inspired me to do this. 

Firstly, the British Heart Foundation is a charity that has a direct relevance to my family and so is a super important charity to support. 

Secondly, working in health research, I have seen the impact that the pandemic has had on really important non-COVID research and charities play such an important role in driving forward new treatments and interventions for patients which make such a difference to their quality of life. Now, more than ever, charities need our support to boost their research funding and every little helps! 

Finally, I need to be healthier and I have been inspired by a friend who has recently shown it is possible to be single minded about making healthier choices, so I thought I'd have a go myself. I don't know if I can do as well as he has, but I'll give it a go!

So, if you can support me by donating a small amount I'd be very grateful.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I am about 50% Cadburys. Fact! Never a day (sometimes every waking hour) goes by without me eating chocolate. I do know it's wrong but I can't stop. Until now!

I'm hoping to reach the ripe old age of 50 later this year. However, there is a history of heart problems in my family and not everyone has made it that far. So, I'm not taking this for granted. It's time to take control, break my bad habits and support the British Heart Foundation who desperately need vital funds to continue their research. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in their 60 year history. And it's led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. That's huge! 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help them keep up the pace of progress. My wobbly willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need it most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Thank you for any support that you can give - money preferably, but also words of encouragement to a sugar deprived Louise!

Name: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Now, I don’t know about anyone else..but this lockdown has brought out thee WORST of me when it comes to my eating habits, snacking has just become the norm😂 but instead of eating what I should it’s more been eating what I want.

So for the month of March, I’ve taken on the Dechox for BHF which to be very honest didn’t sound like much of a challenge, until I actually read into it because its not just chocolate and sweets you have to give up, it’s fizzy drinks too and if you know me..I love my energy drinks😂😅(sorry anyone I interact with in advance cause I’m about to be a real grumpy bitch)

All for an amazing cause though because 9 years ago this July, my grandad Robert passed away due to heart failure. So this ones for you bobbins!

Any donations would be massively appreciated, although you don’t have to a like, comment or share would be great too!

❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Whilst in lockdown I have really tried to fulfil my time by doing stuff that keeps my mind busy. This means I've done a lot of baking and consequently the numbers on the scales keep going up. Chocolate is my best friend and my worst enemy. I love chocolate but chocolate doesn't love me. So as a result I thought what is there more perfect for me to do than have a break from it and raise money for an amazing charity by doing it, I really hope I raise lots of money (because this will be hard for me) but hopefully help me lose some pounds 🤣. Please sponsor me, it will really motivate me to do it!

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

story:
Every year we try and raise money for The BHF in memory of Alan, who we miss every day. This year we are unable to have our normal Alan Doyle Memorial Gala or be together as a team so we would like to raise money the socially distanced way by giving up chocolate and sweets whilst still supporting each other like we normally would. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more.

As my friends and family know I am a massive fan of chocolate and sweets! But for the month of March I shall challenge myself to help raise money for a worthy cause that needs it while money is being spent more on the covid crisis. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

For anyone knows me , will know my loveeeee for chocolate, and this may be harder than I think! But it will definitely be worth it! And despite everything going in the world heart and circulatory diseases are still a big killer in the world. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Back in October of last year my family’s world was turned upside down. My dad went into the hospital thinking he’d be back home that night. We later found out that his heart was extremely poorly. He was moved up to Glasgow Jubilee Hospital were he under went a heart bypass and had his aortic valve replaced. During this time we almost lost him multiple times but we are so grateful for the doctors and nurses that tried everything to keep my dad with us. 

Now four months later he is home with us, life is much different now but I’m grateful he’s still here. I’m doing Dechox because anyone that knows me will know chocolate, sweets and fizzy juice is my down fall so this will be difficult but it’s for an amazing charity. So please dig deep for the BHF, 31 days is a short time it’ll be tough but so worth it. 😊


The pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF have faced in a 60 year history. 

This pandemic is our biggest challenge. Its led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Anyone who knows me knows how much of a chocoholic I am, I don't go longer than a few hours without a sneaky little fix 😋🍫 so this is definitely going to be a 'challenge' 😅 but.. here goes. This March i am giving up chocolate for a whole month to raise money for a cause very close to my heart ❤ 

Please donate if you can, just a small amount will do.. to help British heart foundation keep up their excellent work, researching, finding cures and saving precious lives. 

It would mean the world to me and my 'world' 👨‍👩‍👧‍👧🌏

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation in memory of Malcolm Lightfoot and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

title: Raising Money for Guide Dogs
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Raising Money for Guide Dogs

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
I'm very pleased to announce I will be running the London marathon 2021 on behalf of the guide dogs for the blind association.

The work they do is nothing short of amazing! The guide dogs provide blind people with independence and companionship, this is something that people take for granted everyday and to have this when you feel like it's been taken away from you is such and incredible feeling, if you get the opportunity to visit the guide dogs on an open day you can experience how these wonderful dogs help you through everyday scenarios.

I've grown up around Leamington spa and have lived in the area my whole life, during these years I have often seen guide dogs in training getting walked around Leamington as well as attending some of the open days at the Leamington branch. My family and I have long been supporters of the guide dogs, in fact my auntie and uncle used to raise guide dog puppies and I myself have raised money in the past for the guide dogs.

£60 could buy a harness, lead, collar and bell for a guide dog. 

£30 could pay for a vital vet's appointment. 

£20 could buy a training harness.

Thanks for visiting my page and thank you for your donation if penny helps, I hope to see you at a fundraising event in the near future.
title: Chris's Team Guide Dogs page

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
Thank you for pledging your sporting challenge for 2021. Whether you are running, cycling, skydiving or taking part in an extreme challenge, you are making it count for Guide Dogs. We hope you are raring to go and proud of yourself for joining our team of life-changers! 

The sponsorship money you raise will truly make a difference. £140 could buy a Starter Kit for a new guide dog owner, containing everything they need to start a life with their new guide dog, this includes the iconic white harness. 

Its thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services, like our guide dogs, to people with sight loss. So, a huge thank you and lots of luck for your challenge!

eventName: Running for me and people around the world
story:
I have had Anderson Fabry my whole life. It’s a rare disease that attacks your metabolic system during your lifetime, meaning your kidneys, heart and skin suffer traumatic infection. A genetic mutation that causes the enzymes in your body to slow the process Sphingolipids. Great Ormond street have supported me through my journey from the age of 10, meaning their guidance and care has been invaluable in caring for my rare illness. I’m indebted to them, and will be reliant on their care, knowledge and experience for giving me a brighter future.

I am raising money to show my appreciation to them - all the work and care they have shown me has been amazing I will be running 2 miles a day for 10 days hope you donate what you can.

A truly inspiring story – The little miracle that is Ferne McLindon

Please please please take a moment to read this story....

Over the years, I’ve managed to raise a few quid for charity, thanks to the amazing generosity of my family and friends. This year I’ll be doing the same again, although the driving force behind the decision lies much closer to home.

I would like to share a story, which exemplifies the power of unwavering positivity in the face of the worst possible odds.

Let me introduce you to my own little hero, Ferne McLindon, aged 12.

From the moment this little girl’s family learned that she might not even survive the night, to the day she learned to walk again and play in the snow with her sister, this has been a physical and emotional battle which will have you crying in sadness one minute, before bursting with pride and inspiration the next.

Before you read any further, take a moment to look closely at this recent photo of Ferne (left) and her sister, Izzy. From the big grin on her face as she waits for snowball fight in the garden, you would be forgiven for having no clue of the incredible fight which she and the McLindon family have battled over the past 14 months.
Like most people nowadays, I’m part of a WhatsApp group with a few friends. Daily chat is fairly non-descript, unrepeatable nonsense, with most of the guys adding their tuppence worth at some point. Rewinding a year or so to the end of January 2019, when we noticed that one of the guys, Iain, hadn’t posted anything for a few weeks. While this in itself wasn’t particularly unusual, we soon learned why he had gone quiet - and the news sent shockwaves through the group.

Cut to 13 months later, where Iain, Ferne's Dad, describes the life changing events of the past year:

“On New Year’s Day 2020 Ferne was admitted to Colchester Hospital after becoming unwell at home. She had just celebrated her 11th birthday on 30th December.

It was to our complete shock and dismay that we soon found out Ferne was suffering from a condition called Toxic Shock and Sepsis, caused by a very rare Strep G infection. She was transferred immediately to the Paediatric Intensive Care Unit at Great Ormond Street. After suffering multiple organ failure, Specialists at the hospital delivered the devastating news that Ferne had only a 5% chance of survival. I was convinced that this would be our last night together as a family of four. But alas, we had a fighter in our midst.

In the weeks that followed, Ferne fought with all her might to overcome the odds and the infection. Despite this astonishing battle, she sadly lost both her legs below the knee and the tips of four fingers, while her entire stomach had to be removed. To further compound Ferne’s already tenuous situation, she was also diagnosed with Leukaemia. This turned out to be the reason why she became so unwell in the first place.

Ferne spent around six months of 2020 as an inpatient at Great Ormond St Hospital. During the COVID pandemic the restrictions within the hospital meant Ferne could only be with one parent, while no other visitors were allowed. As you would expect, this was incredibly tough for such a close family.

On to how Ferne was cared for during the time she was in hospital. Despite everything else going on in the world, the staff and volunteers at Great Ormond Street shone through as the true unsung heroes for these children and their families. The utterly selfless nature of everyone at the Hospital is so incredibly important in keeping up the spirits of all the in-patients. With COVID having such a profound impact on day-to-day procedures and visitation within the hospital, the staff were truly amazing at providing entertainment for the children. Without putting too fine a point on things - GOSH saved Ferne’s life - hundreds more like her every year.

Thankfully, Ferne is now in remission, although she continues to receive treatment for Leukaemia. With the help of so many wonderful people, Ferne has learned to walk again and is already looking forward to learning to run in the future.”

Put simply, Ferne’s never give up attitude is utterly inspiring. The strength of will demonstrated by Ferne is incredible – remember she was given only a 5% chance of survival. While I have read and listened to people who regard themselves as experts in how to adopt a positive mental attitude while overcoming adversity, this little girl is the absolute pinnacle of determination and is the only motivation I will ever need. She is an absolute hero!

With Ferne’s story at the forefront, and in conjunction with my running and ultra marathon exploits this year, I have decided to raise funds for Great Ormond Street Hospital. They really are wonderful people and deserve every single plaudit which comes their way.

charity.description:
We are the world’s largest charity dedicated to saving lives through research.
Our vision is to bring forward the day when all cancers are cured.

Cancer Research UK is a registered charity in England and Wales (1089464), Scotland (SC041666), the Isle of Man (1103) and Jersey (247).
charity.name: Cancer Research UK
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 1089464, Scotland SC041666
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Ronnie sadly passed away peacefully in hospital with his family at his side on 15 February 2021.

As most of you are aware Ronnie was diagnosed with throat cancer in 2011, and he faced many challenges throughout the years with regards to the cancer treatments. He was then diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, another challenge he had to live with.

In remembrance of Ronnie, and rather than flowers, we know he would want to help others that are suffering, so please feel free to donate to Cancer Research or Parkinson’s UK. This page is for Cancer Research UK.

Ronnie was a great supporter of a range of people charities, and of the environment. He was always ready to help others and touched many lives wherever he has been. His long career with AMEC took him offshore and overseas to Kazakhstan, Romania and Qatar. Here he introduced ‘green’ initiatives, and in Kazakhstan he won a Global Achievement Award for his programme to support students into the world or work.

He was always proud of his roots in Barrhead and when he returned, he set up the box making company, Gateside Box Limited, with his brother.  Ronnie was an active member of the Lodge Thistle and Crown 1167 Neilston, always keen to be part of the local community.

Although we are all sad now, Ronnie has left us with some wonderful memories, and he would be happy to know that even now he can continue to help others through these donations.

Thank you
title: Ronald (Ronnie) F L Anderson (Cancer Research UK)

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

eventName: A Million Miles for Marie Curie
story:
At Visual Print and Design, we are proud to support a number of local and national charities and the brilliant work that they do. 

We believe that it is our role as a business to offer up our time and resources when we can to help the community, especially as the pandemic has had a detrimental impact on the fundraising efforts of charities and stretched resources.

That’s why, as a team, we decided to collectively walk 1 million steps throughout March to help raise some vital funds for Marie Curie so they can continue to provide frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of dying, death and bereavement.

Team Members

- Graham Hunstone
- Scott Jones
- Charlie Hartley
- Sarah Lawrence
- Rachael Hunt

We have chosen to raise money for Marie Curie in memory of Charles Hunstone, who sadly passed away in January 2021. Marie Curie offered exceptional support for Charles during his last few days and his family will be forever grateful.

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
In March 2020 we lost our beloved Michael, Dad, Grandad, husband, uncle, cousin and friend.

In the final few days we could not have coped without the care and support from the Marie Curie nurses. Their compassion for Michael and his family was so appreciated. With their help we were able to have Michael home with his family and to watch the spring bulbs emerging in his garden. His final wish. 

To show my appreciation, I am attempting to run 100km throughout the month of March. Don't laugh, I have been training!

I will be running with my Marie Curie daffodil pin and thinking of Michael and all the wonderful nurses.

I would be very grateful if you could sponsor me, anything you can spare would be very welcome.

Thank you

Laura

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: 31 miles for the 31 days of March
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am riding 31 miles for the 31 days of March in memory of my sister Linda, for my family, friends & all of the other peoples lives that have been touched by a terminal disease.

Marie Curie Nurses do fantastic exceptional work for people, their families & friends when they need it the most.

If you would like to donate, that's brilliant! Any unused beer tokens, due to COVID, would be appreciated. A big thank you 🤗 on behalf of the nurses for supporting them to carry out the great work that they do!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the Marie Curie charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the Marie Curie charity

Thank you for your support, it is very much appreciated.

Gary Batty

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

Because we can't get out to collect in the usual way, we very much hope you will be able to support us online. The important work of the Marie Curie nurses is needed more than ever in these difficult times. Thank you so much for your donation.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thank you for your donation. To access the recipes please like our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/GariochMarieCurie 

Our Garioch Marie Curie Fundraising group hopes to raise funds by posting well-tried and loved recipes pulled together by our group of 5. We have been unable to do any face-to-face events over the last year and have relied mainly on the continuing generosity from people, through can collections in shops and donations.    Our contribution to The Great Daffodil Appeal this year will be done differently and we hope that this sharing of recipes during March and April might just engender some interest and some much needed funds to support Marie Curie.    The charity provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
This March, Morrisons and Marie Curie are working side by side to raise vital funds for frontline nurses to help dying people and their loved ones.

This has been a hard year for everyone. Weve faced challenging times as a nation, and we know it's the small moments that bring people together. Such moments can be made possible for dying people and their loved ones by the expert care of Marie Curie Nurses, who can bring care, comfort and clarity at the very toughest time. 

Your support means the world to people affected by terminal illness.  From picking your daffodil in-store and wearing it with pride, to taking on your own fundraising challenge you're making vital care possible.

Put simply, without the support people like you highly skilled Marie Curie Nurses couldn't continue giving vital care to people living with a terminal illness and their families.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story:
Hi Everyone, It's Bal here from Zenzero. During March I have decided to take out the 3000 squat challenge with some of the team from Zenzero. It's nearly time and I have been practicing, so I'm ready to raise some funds for Marie Curie UK! If you feel my pain please sponsor me if you can, or why not sign up and join me and the team!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I have decided to walk step up and walk 10,000 steps every day in March to raise money for Marie Curie. This is in memory of my lovely childhood friend Emma’s brother, Alex, who sadly passed away with brain cancer. I know Marie curie were amazing support to the family like so many others ❤️ we never know when we may need this wonderful charity so I’m asking if all my friends could please give a donation no matter how small it will goto such a great cause. 

£25 will pay for a bereavement counsellor to listen, soothe and support someone who’s grieving for an hour. 

£180 pays for a Marie Curie Nurse to provide hands-on care in someone’s home for a full nine hour shift. 

£390 sponsors a hospice bed for a day meaning  someone living with a terminal illness can get expert care when they need it most.

charity.name: Marie Curie
eventName: Sandys walk 180 mile challenge for the great daffodil appeal
story:
During the Great Daffodil Appeal I usually take part in and run many collections across the Anglesey & North Gwynedd area. Sadly all of our collections have been cancelled this year because of Covid, so instead I have decided to get my walking boots on and aim to walk 180 miles in the next 6 weeks.

It cost the charity £180 pounds to provide a family with a Marie Curie nurse for one night's care. Marie Curie nurses provide nursing care and support to people who are living with terminal illness/es in the comfort and safety of the patient's own home.  Nurses arrive at the patient's home at 10pm and stay until 7am the next morning and during that time are on hand to give one-to-one care and support the patient's family/carers to get a good night's rest at the most difficult time.

Please help me to support our local Nursing service by sponsoring me - THANK YOU AND TAKE CARE

Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Marie Curie have helped in my life, I've got first hand experience of the wonderful work they do.  When I was 23 my late Husband was cruelly taken from me, Marie Curie were there for me to help when I felt lonely and vulnerable, in the last weeks of his life, Marie Curie Nurses sat overnight with him taking care of his every need, this gave me a chance to try to sleep which helped in making the next day a little more bearable.  They were always kind, caring and professional with a wonderful empathy both for my lovely Husband and for me.  I could not have got through that time without them.

Doing the Step Into Spring Challenge is a small thing that I do to try to say a big thank you.  I do hope you will help me reach my target.

Thank you

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In March I usually rattle a few collection tins and give out the familiar Marie Curie daffodil badges. As this isn’t possible in 2021, I thought I would set myself the challenge of cycling at least 300km in March and perhaps as far as 300miles. Daffodils are already opening in gardens and verges and hopefully they will spur me on. 🌼🌼 Thank you. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Our mum had a brave 2 year fight with Cancer. She never once got emotional and stayed strong throughout whatever obstacles were thrown her way.

There are no goodbyes wherever you’ll be, you’ll be in our hearts. Rest in peace.

Cancer is only going to be a chapter in your life not the whole story.

Om Sai Ram.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Welcome to Marie Curie's Great Daffodil Appeal! Thank you so much for choosing to support our vital work. Your help really does mean the world to thousands of people living with a terminal illness during these difficult times.

Normally, we would give to a street/store collection or sometimes take part in one.  Because street/store collections are currently suspended, we'd like to raise some money virtually.  Beats standing at a drafty supermarket door!

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
owner: Team MS - WWF 100 Miles in March
story:
WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.

Your support is much appreciated.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
Hi All, 

I am completing a 100 mile walking challenge in March for WWF. This event is via Facebook under the group '100 Miles in March Challenge'. I have a separate fundraising page on Facebook and so far have raised £90. However I know some people may not have Facebook or are comfortable in donating on there. I have set up this page so that more people are able to donate to this charity. The fundraising target is £50 on here so overall I aim to raise £200 for WWF.

I would appreciate all the support I can get. I will be posting weekly updates on Facebook and also will keep anyone else posted by email or group chat. 

 To find out more about WWF, please visit their website on: www.wwf.org.uk  

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.

Your support is much appreciated.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

title: Iqbal Soor

Name: Iqbal Soor

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
My name is Lucas, and me and my friends Bradley, Callum, Jamie, and Sam are ten years old. I read about the children my age and younger who are starving in Yemen and it made me really sad, and so we all decided to try to fundraise to make a difference. We want to be able to help them by fundraising to provide food and shelter. We are going to walk 15 miles in one day to raise money, please sponsor us if you can, thank you. 

'More than five years of fighting has already pushed Yemen and its health system to the brink of collapse. Millions of children lack access to clean water and sanitation facilities and are in desperate need of basic healthcare. Malnutrition is also at an all-time high. 2 million children are acutely malnourished and over 368,000 children under 5 are suffering from severe acute malnutrition and urgently need life-saving food to survive.'

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page, we really appreciate your donation.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

It is a small effort for me, but I know it means so much more on so many levels! Friends and family, I rarely ask, but this time, I ask you to please donate for the cause! Lots of love, kind souls❤️🌈

charity.name: WaterAid
story: WaterAid is working to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. The international not-for-profit organisation works in 28 countries to change the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people. Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

charity.name: WaterAid
story: As part of our company's commitment to support WaterAid, I'm walking at least 12km per day during the month of March as part of the "Walk for Water" campaign.12km is the distance that some people around the world travel in order to collect a bucket of clean water.
title: John’s page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: John’s page

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I'm walking for water so others don't have to. 

4km per day throughout March...

I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive.

I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

I am also walking for myself. Time to get back on track...and this seems a good and achievable (he says confidently!) way of getting fitter whilst doing a little bit of good along the way...

story: I have worked in India and Malawi  and know just how hard daily life can be, particularly for women and children, some as young as 4 or 5, having to  walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid is working to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. The international not-for-profit organisation works in 28 countries to change the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people. Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

My aim is to walk at least 4Km everyday in march.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hi everyone, We have been friends for over 37 years and met at school in at St. Joseph's College in Bradford. We now live in different parts of the UK and we will be walking 4km at the same time everyday for children like Tiyamike. Tiyamike is 14 years old and lives in a remote village in Malawi. She has to walk to collect water every morning, which means she is often late for school. Tiyamike walks around 4km a day for water. We're walking for water so others don't have to.

Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.

Thank you for your support x
